document.docAuthor: Yoshida, Takuma, Nagasaki, Osamu & Hirayama, Tomoko
document.docTitle: Apsilops japonicus Yoshida, Nagasaki & Hirayama, 2011, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of the genus Apsilops Förster (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Cryptinae) from Japan; parasitoid of an aquatic crambid moth

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of the genus Apsilops Förster (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Cryptinae) from Japan; parasitoid of an aquatic crambid moth

subSubSection.paragraph: (Additional images are available at “Checklist of Japanese Ichneumonidae ” by Kazuhiko Konishi: http://cse.naro.affrc.go.jp/ konishi/mokuroku/ apsilops .html)

Hind femur 3.5–4.1 times as long as median width. Hind tibia 7.8–8.9 times as long as apical width. Fifth tarsomeres weakly curved and with large claws. Fifth tarsomere of middle leg 0.7–0.8 times as long as 2 nd– 4 th tarsomeres combined. Fifth tarsomere of hind leg 0.5 times as long as 2 nd– 4 th tarsomeres combined.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology.
Neoschoenobia testacealis
( Lepidoptera : Crambidae ) boring in the leaf petiole of the yellow water lily,
Nuphar subintegerrium
( Nymphaeaceae ). As mentioned in the introduction, the existence of this species on the host had already been reported by Nagasaki (1992 , 2004 ). Females walk down the petiole of the plant and oviposition takes place underwater. This species is a solitary idiobiont ectoparasitoid on larvae and pupae (Nagasaki et al . in prep.). One of the collecting sites is shown in Figure 28 .

Remarks. This species is easily distinguished from the other species of the genus by having mostly black legs. The legs of
A . japonicus
are black except for some brown bands and white stripes or annuli of the male (
Figs 22– 24
), whereas legs of the other species are mostly brown to reddish brown with limited black areas. The scutellum of
A . japonicus
is never tinged with white, but the other species often have white mark on the scutellum. Also the relative length of ovipositor to the hind tibia can be used to discriminate this species from the others. The ovipositor sheath is as long as the hind tibia in
A . japonicus
, but it is longer than the hind tibia in a North American species,
A . sericata
, and shorter in the other species.
